pros: high level overviews. Iterative approaches to corporate strategy foster
cons: At the end of the day, going forward, a new normal that has evolved from generation X
The supervisor I had needed to be trained.

pros: EMCC is a great place to start your career, but they are very limited by their budgets. You'll never make a ton of money working here and in fact, they tend to underpay their employees for the overload of work they all do. People work here because it is a great environment, you have great benefits, and it's good work, but yeah after a few years you'll want to move on.
cons: Not great pay for the work you do, not super organized, not very cohesive, not flexible with work from home.

job_title: Professional Analyst and Professor in Bangor, ME
pros: Community colleges provide essential education to Maine´s working class. Eastern Maine Community College provides a wide variety of academic and professional educational tracks. They are good employers, providing faculty and staff with excellent class rooms, computer services and other support.
cons: Salaries for adjunct faculty make this work more a charity than an occupation. Each course paid less than $2,000, so even carrying a load of four courses per semester would not boost the instructor above poverty wages.  Your rewards are psychic, not financial.  There is also a peculiar policy of not permitting adjuncts to select books to be used in a class.

job_title: Information Technology Intern in Bangor, ME
pros: Great people, I was an intern for 2 years and it was one of the best jobs I have ever had.  The management is very friendly and easy to get along with and the hourly people are just as great.  I made a lot of good friends at EMCC.
cons: I can't really think of any downsides.  I mean you're not going to get rich there, but it's not about that.

pros: It is very rewarding to be able to teach students how to be successful hospitality managers utilizing your work experience as a reference.
cons: The work is contracted on a semester by semester basis, and the compensation depends on how many classes that you teach. You never know what that will be until school starts

review_title: Organization does a lot with a little
pros: Good work environment, friendly colleagues with a lot of pride in the organization
cons: Tight budget, heavily dependent on state funding.  This has resulted in limited growth for many years -- not in terms of student population, but in limited increases in services for students.

pros: A very large, dedicated tutoring center is ready to help you learn.
cons: Tutoring logs are a pain in the rear.
